title: 114_hr785
content: The Act titled "Federal Employee Pension Fairness Act of 2015" repeals FERS revised and further revised annuitant categories. The "Federal Employee Pension Fairness Act of 2015" repeals sections of title 5, United States Code related to annuity computation, annuitant categories, and government contributions. Conforming amendments are also made to section 8401. The "Federal Employee Pension Fairness Act of 2015" repeals certain sections of title 5, United States Code related to annuity computation and annuitant categories. The amendments made by this section will apply on the first day of the first pay period after the enactment of the Act. Former revised or further revised annuitants will be treated as employees for the purposes of chapter 84 of title 5. The "Federal Employee Pension Fairness Act of 2015" repeals annuitant categories under the Foreign Service Act of 1980, specifying applicable percentages for different participant groups based on specific time periods. The "Federal Employee Pension Fairness Act of 2015" repeals annuitant categories under the Foreign Service Act of 1980 and makes amendments regarding government contributions and application timelines. The "Federal Employee Pension Fairness Act of 2015" repeals annuitant categories under the Foreign Service Act of 1980 and deems participants as defined in section 852 for the Foreign Service pension system. The "Federal Employee Pension Fairness Act of 2015" repeals annuitant categories under the Foreign Service Act of 1980 and deems participants as defined in section 852 for the Foreign Service pension system. Additionally, foreign corporations managed and controlled in the United States are treated as domestic corporations under Section 4. The Internal Revenue Code is amended to treat certain corporations managed and controlled in the United States as domestic for income tax purposes. Certain corporations managed and controlled in the United States are treated as domestic corporations if their stock is regularly traded on an established securities market or if their aggregate gross assets are $50,000,000 or more. Certain corporations not regularly traded on an established securities market with aggregate gross assets under $50,000,000 may be treated as domestic corporations if granted a waiver by the Secretary. The Secretary will prescribe regulations to determine when the management and control of a corporation is primarily within the United States, focusing on executive officers and senior management. The regulations will determine the management and control of a corporation in the US, focusing on executive officers and senior management, including individuals from other corporations in the same chain. The regulations will determine that a corporation's management and control in the US is primarily based on assets being managed for investors, with investment decisions made in the US. The effective date for these amendments is two years after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 5. MODIFICATIONS TO RULES RELATING TO INVERTED CORPORATIONS. SEC. 5. MODIFICATIONS TO RULES RELATING TO INVERTED CORPORATIONS. In General, subsection (b) of section 7874 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to treat foreign corporations as domestic if they meet certain criteria, including being a surrogate foreign corporation or an inverted domestic corporation. An inverted domestic corporation is defined as a foreign corporation that undergoes a specified plan after May 8, 2014. After May 8, 2014, if an entity acquires substantially all properties of a domestic corporation or partnership, and after the acquisition, more than 50% of the entity's stock is held by former shareholders of the domestic entity. After May 8, 2014, if an entity acquires the majority of a domestic corporation or partnership's assets, and over 50% of the entity's stock is held by former shareholders or partners of the domestic entity, and the management and control of the expanded affiliated group occurs primarily within the United States. The exception for corporations with substantial business activities in a foreign country states that a foreign corporation will not be considered an inverted domestic corporation if the expanded affiliated group, which includes the entity, has significant business activities in the foreign country where the entity is created or organized. The term 'substantial business activities' is defined by regulations in effect on May 8, 2014. The Secretary may issue regulations increasing the threshold percent in tests for determining substantial business activities. Regulations will determine management and control of an expanded affiliated group primarily within the United States. Regulations apply after May 8, 2014. Regulations will determine that the management and control of an expanded affiliated group is primarily within the United States if executive officers and senior management responsible for strategic decisions are based in the U.S. regardless of their title. An expanded affiliated group has significant domestic business activities if at least 25 percent of employees, employee compensation, assets, or income are based in the United States. The text discusses regulations regarding significant domestic business activities under certain conditions and amendments to the tax code. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years ending after May 8, 2014, including changes to subsections and paragraphs within the tax code.
